correction_response:
This tweet is misleading. The Supreme Court ruling in question pertains to a specific case where a Border Patrol agent was accused of unlawfully entering a property and using excessive force. The court did not rule that Border Patrol can enter any home without a warrant and assault individuals within 100 miles of the border. Furthermore, Fourth Amendment protections do apply within the 100-mile zone, and individuals have the right to remain silent and not consent to a search. However, Border Patrol agents can set up immigration checkpoints within this zone and ask individuals about their citizenship status.

https://www.npr.org/2018/09/20/649187775/federal-agents-board-buses-100-miles-from-border-to-ask-are-you-a-u-s-citizen
